title: Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
summary: Silent killer - colorless, odorless gas. Get everyone out immediately and call 911. Do not re-enter area.

steps.title: Evacuate Immediately
steps.description: Get everyone out of area immediately, including pets. Do not waste time opening windows. Carbon monoxide is invisible and odorless. Move to fresh air. Call 911 from outside.

steps.title: Call 911
steps.description: Call 911 and report suspected carbon monoxide poisoning. Tell them number of victims and symptoms. Do NOT re-enter building until emergency services say it's safe. Fire department will test air.

steps.title: Check for Symptoms
steps.description: Symptoms: headache, dizziness, weakness, nausea, confusion, chest pain. Advanced: loss of consciousness, seizures. Multiple people with flu-like symptoms suggests CO poisoning. Pets affected first.

steps.title: Give Oxygen if Available
steps.description: If trained and oxygen available, administer high-flow oxygen. Hospital treatment with 100% oxygen or hyperbaric chamber may be needed. Keep victims calm and still to reduce oxygen demand.

steps.title: Monitor Victims
steps.description: Even if feeling better in fresh air, all exposed need medical evaluation. Effects can be delayed. Watch for confusion, chest pain, vision problems. Begin CPR if anyone stops breathing.

warnings: Never use generators, grills, or gas appliances indoors
CO poisoning can cause permanent brain damage or death
Victims may not realize they're being poisoned
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 immediately for any suspected CO exposure
All exposed persons need medical evaluation
Seek care even if symptoms improve in fresh air
preventionTips: Install CO detectors on every level of home
Never run vehicles in closed garage
